Journal Story: In less than a week , I'll be headed to Florida for a visit with some family and friends ... then , my brother Tim will transport me to Amicalola State Park to begin my hike . Got a little case of butterflies in my stomach the past few days , as my departure date gets closer . I'm excited and nervous ... I've done a few week long backpacking trips before , but nothing that compares to a thru-hike of the AT ! Looks like the weather is improving there , so that's a good sign ...

These next 3 days are gonna be a blur ... lots to do before heading to Florida for a visit with my brother and his wife . Then , when our visit is done , Tim (" Tumbleweeds ") will drive me to Amicalola State Park , and the big adventure will begin . So far , I haven't convinced him to join me for some time on the trail ...

Leaving here early Thursday morning for my brother's place in Florida . After our visit of several days , "Tumbleweeds" and his wife will be driving me to the AT trailhead in Georgia . Just talked with my good friends Russ and Cheryl ... we are doing our best to meet up somewhere along the trail ... really looking forward to seeing them , and their grandson  . Very soon now , the adventure will begin !

Just to let you know ... the photo that appears on my journal , and in the About me section , was taken last summer in the Bob Marshall Wilderness  here in Montana ... in the background is the Chinese Wall , a very prominent feature in " The Bob " .
Enjoying a few more days in Florida with Tim and Patty before heading to the trailhead ...

Helping my brother Tim replace the screen on his screen room on his dock ... it's like the old "Keystone Cops " movies , only crazier ... delayed the start of my hike again ... was supposed to be on the trail tomorrow , but didn't realize it's my niece's college graduation ceremony on Saturday , May 12th ... of course I'll be staying for that ! Will be heading for thr trailhead within a few days after that ... I'll probably take Amtrak or Greyhound to get there ... didn't realize it's an 8 hour drive from Tim's house ... that's a lot to ask . We are having a great visit here in Florida !

leaving Florida today ... rained on and off during the night ... my brother Tim is driving me to the trailhead ... I need to get some supplies along the way ... we'll probably be on the road all day today , find a place to stay tonight and check out the area in the morning ... probably won't start my hike until Wednesday ...

Visited Amicalola State Park today ... beautiful place ! Staying one more night in a motel in nearby Dahlonega ... then back to Amicalola Falls in the morning . It's raining now , and promises to be a wet start tomorrow , with up to 2" of rain expected ... not the start I had hoped for , but we shall see what the morning brings ...
getting a late start today ... had to drive back to the motel to retrieve my hiking hat ... raining lightly ... signed in at the visitor's center ... I'm thru-hiker #2,618 ...

In a motel in Gainesville , Ga.    Had a real scary night in my tent at Gooch Mountain (shelter was full). It was a tough day on the trail ... got drenched twice , and got lost for a couple of hours when I saw a white blaze and thought it was leading me up an old forest service road. Ran into some fishermen who directed me to where the AT crossed the road , and got back on the trail. The scary part wasn't from any wildlife , or from the downpouring rain ... it was from the way my heart was acting ...had a very rapid heartbeat , then my heart would just stop and give 2 pounding beats ...it would go thru 8-10 series of stopping and two pounding beats , then go back to a rapid beat...it went on for hours , and I was afraid to go to sleep.I finally dozed off ,and it was a little better in the morning. I decided to get off the trail and find a motel and re-evaluate my hiking plans ... that's where I am now ... will spend another night here and call my doctor in the morning , and see what he recommends .

Well ... I'm here in Gainesville , Ga. at a motel where hiker shuttle driver Ron Brown delivered me on Saturday. Rented a car , and am headed to visit some good friends in NC. This may be the end of my AT dream ... it rained pretty much non-stop the first 4 days on the trail , and hard as I tried , everything I was carrying got soaked . But the thing that took me off the trail was the issues I had with my heart ... I think I just over stressed myself and maybe overheated from wearing my rain gear. It scared the heck out of me. Feeling much better now . Maybe I will have a rest and get back on the trail , but it's doubtful . I met some great people on the trail and wish them well , as they continue their hikes. Will update my journal after visiting my friends and deciding what to do next ...

It's been about a week and a half since I got off the trail and ended my hike . I am truly disappointed that my hike ended so early on ... after all the preparation and anticipation , it was a real letdown , to say the least. I did learn a couple of valuable lessons along the way . I knew my pack was heavy starting out , and that I had decided to carry some extra weight to allow me to be more comfortable in camp. I struggled with the weight constantly , and believe that's one of the factors that ended my hike. The AT is a strenuous hike , and the added weight really took a toll on my body. The other thing I would have done differently was my poor eating habits . I knew that it was important to consume a lot of calories in order to replenish the energy that was required to do such a strenuous hike. Although I only averaged about 8 and 1/2 miles a day , I was exhausted at the end of the day , and didn't make the effort to eat properly ... that was a serious mistake . I did make an effort to stay hydrated , but did run out of water once ... some of the water sources were farther from the trail than I expected , and the one time I ran out , I gave up looking for the water source and continued on ... not a smart choice. So ... there were several things I could have done better , that's for sure. The AT was more difficult than I expected ... lots of ups and downs . But it was alao beautiful ! The hardwood forests were even more beautiful than I had expected. The greenery that you walk through had a glow to it that I will never forget . The views were limited , but the forest was remarkable ... I loved it ! My adventure on the AT was cut very short due to my health , but I met some wonderful people along the trail and will always remember their kindness and friendship . I am so thankful for all the hard work that all the trail workers have done to make the AT such a remarkable place ... it's amazing , the effort that it takes to build and maintain the trail is obvious ... and impressive. Best of luck to all past , current and future AT hikers ...  you are an inspiration to us all .

Just wanted to thank everyone who signed my guest book ... your inspiring words were so welcome . To my wife ,Bev ... without your support , I would not have even made the attempt to hike the AT. And my family and friends back in Montana , and elsewhere , were also very supportive ... thank you all so much !

Hi ... it's been a couple of months since I got off the trail due to an irregular heartbeat. I've been through many tests , and am now taking a beta blocker to help regulate my erratic heartbeat. I am scheduled to see a cardiologist in early September , to see what's next in this process. I've thought a lot about the AT , and lately have been wondering if there will be a chance for me to make another attempt to hike the trail . I feel as if I have some unfinished business  there to attend to ...   Time will tell ... hopefully I'll get another chance . I would like to thank Ron Brown ,a well known AT hiker shuttle service , who came to my rescue AT Gooch Gap . Ron went above and beyond what was needed to help me that day , and I am forever grateful to him . I would highly recommend Ron to any hikers requiring transportation AT or near the southern end of the AT. And he's quite an entertaining guy , too ! Thanks again , Ron ... you're the best !
